channel.title: Engine K20A?
channel.description: Can a K20a engine fit in a Chevy 98 S10?

item.title: Engine K20A?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Bebe, post:12, topic:398881”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=496020.msg3642505#msg3642505 date=1309117706]

haha funny how arrogant you people are that you think the american motor is more reliable than the Japanese one.

I ain’t saying the american one is more reliable, but they don’t rev the nuts off of them. The slower an engine is turning, the less wear on it’s components. Also, if you go and modify a small engine enough to produce substantial power, it’s going to make a hell of a lot more heat, further shortening it’s life. A japanese engine, if taken up to or around red line regularly isn’t going to see 150,000 km on the clock.
[/quote]You silly boys and your love for low revving high displacement engines. Engine Speed + Forced Induction > displacement. If you properly maintenance your vehicle any engine can be reliable
“There is no replacement for displacement” ;)[/quote]

That’s just not right at all, no high revving forced induction engine would last as long as a lower revving, naturally aspirated motor that was maintained the same way, it’s simple physics. There truly is no replacement for displacement, there is a reason for that statement. Think about it, anything you can do to a smaller displacement motor, you can do to a large displacement motor. Forced induction? Yep. Higher RPMs? Yep. But there is one thing you can’t do to a smaller motor, add displacement.

Read full topic

item.title: Engine K20A?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

haha funny how arrogant you people are that you think the american motor is more reliable than the Japanese one.

I ain’t saying the american one is more reliable, but they don’t rev the nuts off of them. The slower an engine is turning, the less wear on it’s components. Also, if you go and modify a small engine enough to produce substantial power, it’s going to make a hell of a lot more heat, further shortening it’s life. A japanese engine, if taken up to or around red line regularly isn’t going to see 150,000 km on the clock.

item.title: Engine K20A?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

haha funny how arrogant you people are that you think the american motor is more reliable than the Japanese one.

My 1989 Chevy S10 came with a 4.3L V6 in it, it blew a head gasket at 312,000 miles and I replaced it with a 5.7L 350ci V8, and expect to get another 300k+ out of it, don’t know how much more reliable you can get.

Read full topic

item.title: Engine K20A?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Why would you try to ruin a perfectly good American truck with a shitty little japanese engine? Put a V8 in it, I put a 350ci (5.7L) small block V8 in my 1989 S10, and it runs great. If you really want to race it they now make an aluminum block 454ci (7.4L) small block chevy V8 that will fit right in there the same, and it would be bad ass.

edit:
As to your shitty 4 cyl jap engine, of course they can be made fast, anything can be with enough money. But the bottom line is that there is no replacement for displacement, and if you spend $5000 USD on a nice American V8 you would have to spend at least $20,000 or $30,000 to make a little foreign four banger as fast. For the record, I bought a GM crate engine replacement for a 96 full size Chevy for my truck, it cost $1200, the various mounting brackets and accessories I needed to make it work in my truck ran me somewhere around $600ish, and now I have a new motor and it works great, you should try something similar maybe.

Read full topic
